docs.abstract: Is Midtown a place? Or a state of mind?
docs.snippet: Is Midtown a place? Or a state of mind?
docs.lead_paragraph: Steve writes: Most would agree that Midtown Manhattan ends at 59th Street, but where does it start? I just moved to the city a year ago, but to me, it seems that Midtown begins at 14th Street. My partner claims it’s 34th Street. Who is right?

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Where Midtown Ends
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: They’re poorly constructed and easily confused — but mine is the only gadget I can trust.
docs.snippet: They’re poorly constructed and easily confused — but mine is the only gadget I can trust.
docs.lead_paragraph: My phone is a honey pot for Emirati hackers, my laptop is a 24/7 advertising consultant, and my TV remote has microphones that would’ve made the Stasi blush. But just above the tracking-induced grinding of my teeth, I can hear a pleasant sound at home: the reassuring droning and clunking sound of a robot butler, smart enough to make my floors slightly cleaner but far too stupid to do anything else. This bumbling gadget obeys me and me alone. If I press its single button, it dies, while another press resumes the slow, Sisyphean tidying. There is no power higher than me and my ability to press this button, no secret god or governor buried in the privacy policy I’ll never read, nothing inside it but my grime and its cheap Chinese circuits. It is quite literally the only gadget I trust.

headline.main: Letter of Recommendation: Dumb Robot Vacuums

docs.abstract: Home-funeral guides believe that families can benefit from tending to — and spending time with — the bodies of their deceased.
docs.snippet: Home-funeral guides believe that families can benefit from tending to — and spending time with — the bodies of their deceased.
docs.lead_paragraph: Heidi Boucher loaded two big straw baskets into her Toyota Highlander. She always kept them packed, ready for death. Inside were a pair of leather work gloves and a hammer, a bunch of bed pads, a few adult diapers (dead bodies sometimes leak), Q-tips for cleaning ears, noses and mouths and for applying lipstick, cotton balls, disinfectant spray, a plastic zip bag of safety pins to help drape silk and other fabrics around a gurney or casket, a small screwdriver to tightly close a casket, latex gloves, a hairbrush and oils infused with rose, lavender and rosemary.

headline.main: The Movement to Bring Death Closer

docs.abstract: Why limit yourself to dogs and cats?
docs.snippet: Why limit yourself to dogs and cats?
docs.lead_paragraph: Kat writes: My boyfriend and I want to get a pet. A cat makes sense for our small apartment, but he is against having a litter box. He wants a dog and plans to build a “dog toilet” to allow it to use the bathroom autonomously. I think a dog is implausible, whereas a cat would be a great companion for our ferret, Banjo.

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Getting a Second Pet in a Small Apartment
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: How an internal power struggle, a New York State investigation and accusations of fraud and betrayal on all sides have left the longtime leader of the gun-rights organization reeling.
docs.snippet: How an internal power struggle, a New York State investigation and accusations of fraud and betrayal on all sides have left the longtime leader of the gun-rights organization reeling.
docs.lead_paragraph: Wayne LaPierre was sitting in a chair with his hands over his ears, looking straight down. “It was horribly painful,” he said of the nearly two years of investigations, intrigue and infighting that have roiled the National Rifle Association, which he has led since 1991. Now, a once-invincible organization, and its chief, are girding for a legal reckoning. “I mean,” LaPierre said, looking up, “it’s the most painful period of my life.”

headline.main: Inside Wayne LaPierre’s Battle for the N.R.A.
headline.print_headline: Wayne LaPierre’s Battle for the N.R.A.
